trans-unit.source: How to use queue storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use queue storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the queue storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the queue storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.
trans-unit.target: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:

trans-unit.source: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.
trans-unit.target: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.

trans-unit.source: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.

trans-unit.source: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access queues:
trans-unit.target: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access queues:

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.

trans-unit.source: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.
trans-unit.target: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.

trans-unit.source: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:
trans-unit.target: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:

trans-unit.source: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:

trans-unit.source: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.
trans-unit.target: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.

trans-unit.source: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.
trans-unit.target: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.

trans-unit.source: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.

trans-unit.source: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.
trans-unit.target: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.

trans-unit.source: A cloud_queue_client object lets you get reference objects for queues.
trans-unit.target: A cloud_queue_client object lets you get reference objects for queues.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a cloud_queue_client object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a cloud_queue_client object.

trans-unit.source: Use the cloud_queue_client object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the cloud_queue_client object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.

trans-unit.source: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.
trans-unit.target: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.

trans-unit.source: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new cloud_queue_message.
trans-unit.target: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new cloud_queue_message.

trans-unit.source: Next, call the add_message method.
trans-unit.target: Next, call the add_message method.

trans-unit.source: A cloud_queue_message can be created from either a string or a byte array.
trans-unit.target: A cloud_queue_message can be created from either a string or a byte array.

trans-unit.source: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message 'Hello, World':
trans-unit.target: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message 'Hello, World':

trans-unit.source: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the peek_message method.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the peek_message method.

trans-unit.source: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.
trans-unit.target: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.

trans-unit.source: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.
trans-unit.target: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.

trans-unit.source: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.
trans-unit.target: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.

trans-unit.source: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.
trans-unit.target: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.

trans-unit.source: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.
trans-unit.target: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.

trans-unit.source: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: When you call get_message, you get the next message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: When you call get_message, you get the next message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: A message returned from get_message becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.
trans-unit.target: A message returned from get_message becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.

trans-unit.source: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call delete_message.
trans-unit.target: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call delete_message.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: Your code calls delete_message right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Your code calls delete_message right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.

trans-unit.source: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).
trans-unit.target: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).

trans-unit.source: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.
trans-unit.target: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses the get_messages method to get 20 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses the get_messages method to get 20 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message using a for loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message using a for loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.

trans-unit.source: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to get_messages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.
trans-unit.target: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to get_messages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.

trans-unit.source: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.
trans-unit.target: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The download_attributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.
trans-unit.target: The download_attributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.

trans-unit.source: The approximate_message_count method gets the approximate number of messages in the queue.
trans-unit.target: The approximate_message_count method gets the approximate number of messages in the queue.

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the delete_queue_if_exists method on the queue object.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the delete_queue_if_exists method on the queue object.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of Queue storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of Queue storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
